msItem.locus: Passages distributed in texts I-1, I-2 and I-3 (fols. 2r-178v).
msItem.title: VI) Mäzmurä dǝngǝl “Psalter of the Virgin”
msItem.rubric:
Nomina sacra; headings and numbers of the psalms and other texts; incipits of the texts (usually written in alternating red and black lines); numbers of portions and names of Hebrew letters in Ps. 118; numbers and first lines (usually two) of the poems from Mäzmurä dǝngǝl; abbreviated refrains in Wǝddase Maryam (s. Abbreviations); elements of the punctuation signs; Additiones 1, 2.
In the first fol. of text I-4, the lines are written alternately in red and black.

div.span: [Fol. 2r, l.1]: Come to me, David, the King of Israel,
Master of beautiful psalms and sweet of voice.
Give me understanding of all the parables and interpretation thereof,
So that I may praise the Virgin Mary,
፭፡ እንተ፡ ትሔውጽ፡ ከመ፡ ጎሕ፡ ድኅረ፡ ለያልይ።
ስብሐታቲኪ፡ ማርያም፡ ከመ፡ እንተ፡ ሕልቀት፡ አድሎኩ።
[Fol. 178v, l.14]: Who is she, says the revelation,
That looks on [us] as the dawn after nights?
For your sake, Mary, the sun rises;
The wings of your love are wings of burning fire
Your praises, Mary, I have prepared as [finger] rings,
When I have named each of them (?).
Give me what I long for and what I seek.
In song and in psalmody I proclaimed your name
And the work which you have entrusted me with I have accomplished.

msItem.title: V) ʾAnqäṣä bǝrhan “Gate of Light”
msItem.rubric:
Nomina sacra; headings and numbers of the psalms and other texts; incipits of the texts (usually written in alternating red and black lines); numbers of portions and names of Hebrew letters in Ps. 118; numbers and first lines (usually two) of the poems from Mäzmurä dǝngǝl; abbreviated refrains in Wǝddase Maryam (s. Abbreviations); elements of the punctuation signs; Additiones 1, 2.
In the first fol. of text I-4, the lines are written alternately in red and black.

p.span: [Fol. 194va, l.1]: Praise and homage to Our Lady Mary. The holy one and the blessed one, the praised and the happy one, the glorious and the exalted one, the
light, the ladder of life and the abode of the Divinity, the Holy of Holies you are…

listBibl.bibl: Uppsala O Etiop. 1 (16th cent.), fols. 252r-260v (LöfUpp 32, n°4);
BritMus Orient. 12467 (1660), fols. 161v-166r (StrBritLib 23, n°17 [s. also nos. 18-25]);
JRyM Ethiopian 5 (18th cent.), fols. 158rb-163vb (StrJRyM 7-9, no. 5 and pl. 8).

msItem.title: IV) Wǝddase Maryam “Praise of Mary”
msItem.rubric:
Nomina sacra; headings and numbers of the psalms and other texts; incipits of the texts (usually written in alternating red and black lines); numbers of portions and names of Hebrew letters in Ps. 118; numbers and first lines (usually two) of the poems from Mäzmurä dǝngǝl; abbreviated refrains in Wǝddase Maryam (s. Abbreviations); elements of the punctuation signs; Additiones 1, 2.
In the first fol. of text I-4, the lines are written alternately in red and black.

div.span: : Behold, behold, the feet of my intelligence are standing,
My eyes are looking up with devotion toward the third heaven
To praise you, Mary, according to their number and ability.
ማርያም፡ ርግብ፡ በሐመልማለ፡ ወርቅ፡ ሥርጉተ፡ ገቦ፨
[Fol. 194rb, l.13]: Blessed is the man who has been endowed with the spirit of your grace,
So that he may praise you and you only, [standing] face to face with you,
Mary, the dove whose side is adorned with the verdure of gold;
And blessed is he who knows how to rejoice at your greatness -
Prepare for him a reward in heaven and on earth.

listBibl.bibl: Uppsala O Etiop. 1 (16th cent.), fols. 231-251 (LöfUpp 32, n°4);
BritMus Orient. 12467 (1660), fols. 152r-161v (StrBritLib 23, n°17 [s. also nos. 18-25]);
JRyM Ethiopian 5 (18th cent.), fols. 146ra-158rb (StrJRyM 7-9, no. 5 and pl. 8).

note.span: Each daily portion of Wǝddase Maryam is followed by a short poem similar in metrical structure to those of Mäzmurä dǝngǝl. A poem of the same kind also opens the book. For excerpts from these poems s. Incipit and Explicit.

msItem.title: III) Mäḥalǝyä mäḥalǝy "Song of Songs"
msItem.rubric:
Nomina sacra; headings and numbers of the psalms and other texts; incipits of the texts (usually written in alternating red and black lines); numbers of portions and names of Hebrew letters in Ps. 118; numbers and first lines (usually two) of the poems from Mäzmurä dǝngǝl; abbreviated refrains in Wǝddase Maryam (s. Abbreviations); elements of the punctuation signs; Additiones 1, 2.
In the first fol. of text I-4, the lines are written alternately in red and black.

div.span: [Fol. 171r, l.1]: Song of Songs, of Solomon.
Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth.
Your breasts are more pleasant than wine.
ከመ፡ ወሬዛ፡ ኀየል፡ ውስተ፡ አድባረ፡ ቤቴል፨
... and if not, then like a young hart on the hills of Bethel.
... give me that which I long for and which I seek.
In song and in psalmody will I speak out your name
And the work which you have entrusted me with I have accomplished.

listBibl.bibl: Uppsala O Etiop. 1 (16th cent.), fols. 212v-227r (LöfUpp 31, no. 4);
BritMus Orient. 12467 (1660), fols. 143r-151v (StrBritLib 23, no. 17 [s. also nos. 18-25]);
JRyM Ethiopian 5 (18th cent.), fols. 139r-146r (StrJRyM 7-9, no. 5 and pl. 8).

note.span: The last verse of Song of Songs is followed by the corresponding poem from Mäzmurä d
ǝngǝl (for the Italian translation of the poem s.
O. RAINERI, Salmi etiopici di Cristo e della Vergine, Roma 2005, 186-187).

msItem.title: II) Mäḥalǝyä näbiyat "The Canticles of the Prophets"
msItem.rubric:
Nomina sacra; headings and numbers of the psalms and other texts; incipits of the texts (usually written in alternating red and black lines); numbers of portions and names of Hebrew letters in Ps. 118; numbers and first lines (usually two) of the poems from Mäzmurä dǝngǝl; abbreviated refrains in Wǝddase Maryam (s. Abbreviations); elements of the punctuation signs; Additiones 1, 2.
In the first fol. of text I-4, the lines are written alternately in red and black.

div.span: [Fol. 154v, l.1]: The Canticles of the Prophets and the prayer of Moses.
Let us praise God the praised, who is praised;
The horse and its rider He has thrown into the sea.
[Fol. 170r, l.22]: … and the glory of your people Israel.
O Mary, do not forget me now,
Before I reach the time of old age.
O compassionate, full of mercy like a river!
Since I am overpowered and overridden with despondency –
When shall I find what I hope for?
Glory be to the Father, the Son and the Holy Spirit,
For ever and unto the ages of ages.

listBibl.bibl: Uppsala O Etiop. 1 (16th cent.), fols. 193v-212r (LöfUpp 31, no. 4);
BritMus Orient. 12467 (1660), fols. 129v-142v (StrBritLib 22, no. 17 [s. also nos. 18-25]);
JRyM Ethiopian 5 (18th cent.), fols. 126r-138v (StrJRyM 7-9, no. 5 and pl. 8).

p.span: ፩፡ ብፁዕ፡ ብእሲ፡ ዘኢሖረ፡ በምክረ፡ ረሲዓን፨

div.span: [Fol. 2r, l.1]: Come to me, David, the King of Israel,
Master of beautiful psalms and sweet of voice.
Give me understanding of all the parables and interpretation thereof,
So that I may praise the Virgin Mary,
… and I took away disgrace from the children of Israel.
… I shall offer you exceeding praise

listBibl.bibl: Uppsala O Etiop. 1 (16th cent.), fols. 1r-193r (LöfUpp 31, no. 4);
BritMus Orient. 12467 (1660), fols. 8r-129r (StrBritLib 22, no. 17 [s. also nos. 18-25]);
JRyM Ethiopian 5 (18th cent.), fols. 4r-163vb (StrJRyM 7-9, no. 5 and pl. 8).

note.span: is followed by the corresponding poem from Mäzmurä dǝngǝl (for the Italian translation of the poem s.
O. Raineri, Salmi etiopici di Cristo e della Vergine, Roma 2005,

Made of 198.0 folios, of which 0.0 blank, in 25.0 quires.
31.0 27.0 8.5
supportDesc.condition: The leather cover on the spine is damaged, partly missing.

layout.ab: Ruling is mostly visible; pricking is partly visible.
The upper line is written above the ruling.
The bottom line is written above the ruling.
In many fols. the scribe did not used the bottom ruled line.

layout.note: Texts IV and V. Data for fol. 172. In texts IV and V, the right margin is very narrow (trimmed?).
layout.ab: Ruling is mostly visible; pricking is partly visible.
The upper line is written above the ruling.
The bottom line is written above the ruling.
In many fols. the scribe did not used the bottom ruled line.

list.item: I. Colon; short line with dots above and below (säräz; usually before and after abbreviations)
II. Four dot asterisk (mostly after rubricated lines); nine dot asterisk (mostly after non-rubricated lines)

III. Chain of black and red dots; chain of red and black dashes (mostly used before and after poems from Mäzmurä dǝngǝl, s. Varia, and between portions of Wǝddase Maryam); two chains of red and black dashes with a row of nine dot asterisks between them (e.g., fols. 154r, 170v, 194r).
In Wǝddase Maryam, refrains of each daily portion are occasionally abbreviated to their first word or part of the first word (e.g., fol. 179va, l.4; 181rb, l.6).

p.span: ፡ ዘእማሆይ፡ ብሩር፡ ዘውዴ፡ ወስመ፡ ክርስትናሀ፡ ወለተ፡ ቂርቆስ፡ ወስመ፡ አቡሀ፡ ወልደ፡ ሩፋኤል፡ ወስመ፡ እማ፡ ወለተ፡ እግዚእ፡ ወብእሲሀ፡ ወልደ፡ ማርያም፡ ወእሁሀ፡ ገብረ፡ አረጋዊ፡ ወእህቱ፡ ወለተ፡ ጊወርጊስ፡ ወውሉዳ፡ ገብረ፡ ኢየሱስ፡ ገብረ፡ ተክለሃይማኖት። አቶ፡ ሐጐ[sic]፡ ወልደ፡ ገብርኤል፡
ኦአበውየ፡ ወአሀውየ፡ ሶበ፡ ታነብብዎ፡ ለዝንቱ፡ መጽሀፍ፡ ኢትርስኡኒ፡ ለአመትሙ

q.p: Fol. 1v: This book is of to ˀǝmmahoy Bǝrur Zäwde, whose baptismal name is Wälättä Qirqos. Her father’s name is Wäldä Rufaˀel, her mother’s name is Wälättä ˀƎgziˀ, her husband is Wäldä Maryam, her brother is Gäbrä ˀArägawi, his sister is Wälätta Giwärgis, her sons are Gäbrä ˀIyäsus and Gäbrä Täklähaymanot, ˀato Ḥagwä[s] Wäldä Gäbrǝˀel.

span.span: O my fathers and my brothers, when you read this book, do not forget your servant Wälättä Qirqos.

p.span: ፡ ዝንቱ፡ መጽሀፍ፡ ዘእማሆይ፡ ብሩር፡ ዘውዴ፡ ዘወሀበት፡ ለማርያም፡ ሰበያ፡ ወስመ፡ ክስትናሀ፡ ወለተ፡ ቂርቆስ፡ ወስመ፡ አቡሀ፡ ወልደ፡ ሩፋኤል፡ ወስመ፡ እማ፡ ወለተ፡ እግዚእ፡ ወእሁሀ፡ ገብረ፡ አረጋዊ፡ ወአሀቲሀ፡ ወለተ፡ ጊወርጊስ፡ ወለተ፡ ኪዳን፡ ወእህተ፡ እማ፡ ወለተ፡ ሚካኤል። ሱም፡ አጋሜ፡ ወልዱ፡ ዘመፈስ

span.span: Fol. 197r: In the name of the Father, the Son and the Holy Spirit, One God. This book is of ˀǝmmahoy Bǝrur Zäwde who donated it to Maryam Säbäya; her baptismal name is Wälättä Qirqos, her father’s name is Wäldä Rufaˀel, her mother’s name is Wälättä ˀƎgziˀ, her brother is Gäbrä ˀArägawi, her sisters are Wälättä Giwärgis and Wälättä Kidan, her maternal aunt is Wälättä Mikaˀel.
Šum ˀAgame (is) däğğazmač Wäldä Mikaˀe[l], the son of Zä-Mänfäs Qǝddus and Wälättä Muse.

p.span: Fol. 197v: Calendar notes with indications of new moon dates for each month and memories of saints falling on the days of new moons.

list.item: - Each psalm, each prophetic canticle and each chapter of “Song of Songs” are followed by a poem from Mäzmurä Dǝngǝl, usually separated from the preceding and the following texts by chains of red and black dashes. For the Italian translation of these poems s. O. RAINERI, Salmi etiopici di Cristo e della Vergine, Roma, 2005, 133-187. - Exhortation to the reader to pray for the donor: fol. 2r (upper margin). - Minor notes in the upper margin: fols. 91v, 114r, 193r (partly cut).

binding.decoNote: Wooden boards covered with reddish-brown tooled leather; textile inlays. Two pairs of sewing stations.
Two pairs of chains of endband stitches at the spine cover.

origin.origDate: First half of the 19th century. In Additio 2, ʾǝmmahoy Bǝrur Zäwde appears as a contemporary or a relative of däğğazmač Wäldä Mikaʾel, the governor of ʿAgame (a son of däğğazmač Subagadis).

projectDesc.p: Encoded according to TEI P5 Guidelines.

person.persName: ʾǝmmahoy Bǝrur Zäwde (s. the donation note, fol. 197r).

revisionDesc.change: transformed from mycore to TEI P5
